author: Simon Mullock
title: Steven Gerrard says management is brutal and he would have been stupid to take a job he wasn't ready for
text:
Sport Steven Gerrard says management is brutal and he would have been stupid to take a job he wasn't ready for The Liverpool legend has been talking about his return to the club where he has taken a role in the Reds' Academy Share Gerrard refused to rush into management this summer (Photo: Getty)   Thank you for subscribing!   
Steven Gerrard had to do the dirty work when he was a teenage apprentice with dreams of making the grade at Liverpool . 
Two decades on, after a playing career that saw him captain both his club and country, the ­36-year-old is back on the Anfield proving ground. 
Gerrard is returning to L4 to take up a role in Liverpool’s Academy. 
His ultimate aim is to assume the office once occupied by legends, such as Bill Shankly, Bob Paisley, Kenny Dalglish... and now Jurgen Klopp . 
But it will be a matter of one step at a time as he looks to get a foothold in the fabled Liverpool Boot Room. Gerrard is taking it one step at a time at Melwood (Photo: Getty) 
Gerrard, who will combine his coaching role and working as a pundit for BT Sport, said: “To become a good player, you have got to do an apprenticeship and learn certain values. 
“You have to learn how the profession works, you have to watch first-team players who are better than you. Gerrard is combining his coaching role with being a pundit on BT Sport (Photo: BT Sport) 
“You learn the good and the bad off senior players, you get close to them – and, when you are ready, you dislodge them – that’s when you move in. 
“I don’t see management as being much different. I’ve put the cones out before and I’ve pumped up the footballs. 
“I even used to clean the staff toilets – when Joe Corrigan was in there! I’ve now got dreams and aspirations about one day being a manager or a coach. Gerrard is back where it all began (Photo: Getty) 
“And to have the opportunity to learn and develop at the club I love, among my own people, is a massive thrill for me.” 
Klopp was instrumental in bringing Gerrard home. 
Opportunities to work at Premier League and senior level were offered to Stevie G. 
But Gerrard felt it would be better to put himself on a learning curve rather than a fast-track to possible oblivion. 
He said: “The name you had on the back of your shirt can become a problem. 
“It’s not necessarily the players concerned, it’s the fact that other people get excited and want to put big opportunities in front of you. Klopp was key in bringing Gerrard back (Photo: Andrew Powell/Liverpool FC via Getty) 
“I had them, chances to be a No.1 or a No.2, but I understood that, if you take the wrong ­opportunity at the wrong time and act on reputation, sentiment or emotion, then you could find it hard. 
“Just because you’ve been a good player doesn’t mean you are going to be a great manager. 
“I don’t want to name names because that would be ­disrespectful, but I have seen it so many times. 
“Management is so brutal. I think it would have been very stupid and immature to go into a position when I wasn’t ready.” 
“I decided there’s no rush. If it takes me five or 10 years, I don’t care because, at the moment, I’m not ready for the jobs I would ultimately want.”
